all_summaries: This paper proposes a robust federated learning method, SMRFL, which addresses the issue of non-malicious perturbations in edge networks by leveraging sharpness-aware minimization to encourage convergence to flat minima, improving model robustness and achieving comparable convergence rates to standard FL methods despite model degradation from perturbations. Experiments on real-world datasets demonstrate that SMRFL outperforms baselines like FedAvg in handling both uplink and downlink perturbations, maintaining higher test accuracy and faster convergence, especially under non-IID data conditions.

A new robust federated learning method called SMRFL is introduced, which uses sharpness-aware minimization to enhance model robustness against non-malicious perturbations in edge networks. The method converges to flat minima by incorporating SAM, improving resistance to model degradation from both uplink and downlink perturbations. Experiments on real-world datasets show that SMRFL outperforms baselines like FedAvg in test accuracy under various perturbation scenarios, demonstrating its effectiveness in handling non-malicious perturbations. Theoretical analysis confirms that SMRFL achieves a convergence rate comparable to standard FL without perturbations. SMRFL also excels in non-IID data settings, maintaining high accuracy despite increased data heterogeneity and perturbation effects.
